body:
Using `git bisect` I was able to narrow it down to (seemingly) commit 221e2af34958d0de3cf1121d9b95f36767d39c01

I'll see if I can determine if this is an intentional or accidental change in behavior.
Yea this looks accidental when switching to expressions for performance gain.  Also there's appears to  be no unit test so that's why it wasn't caught.
Yep, the expression does not take into account the destination type, it just does the default of the resolved type.
I'm still familiarizing myself with the codebase but may have some time tomorrow to try my hand at a PR. Thanks for the quick confirmation ðŸ˜„

@kogir I'm looking at it right now.

Looks doable just need to refactor a few things, and @jbogard it looks like some more obsolete code can be deleted :)
lol great. Well I think this might be the last one we include in 5.0.1 to get it out the door.

issue.title: Conditional mapping from int to int? causes error in 5.0.1
issue.body:
I have a mapping like this:

```
CreateMap<Order, OrderVm>()
    .ForMember(dest => dest.CustomerId, opt => opt.MapFrom(src => (src.Customer != null) ? src.Customer.Id : (int?)null));
```

destination.CustomerId is of type int?
source.Customer.Id is of type int

Basically, if the Customer property in the source object is null, set the destination CustomerId property to null, otherwise set it to the Id property inside the source Customer object.

In version 5.0.0 and below this would fine but in 5.0.1 I get the following error:

> System.InvalidOperationException : Rewriting child expression from type 'System.Int32' to type 'System.Nullable`1[System.Int32]' is not allowed, because it would change the meaning of the operation. If this is intentional, override 'VisitUnary' and change it to allow this rewrite.

Is there a different way of achieving this?

issue.title: Failure mapping from short? to short
